November 2003

NOTE

This report was prepared by S. Sahni.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is supporting subregional cooperation in eastern 
South Asia based on the establishment of the South Asian Growth Quadrangle, comprising 
Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, and Nepal (BBIN). Regional technical assistance (TA) has helped 
the participating countries establish an institutional framework (a country advisers’ group and 
sector working groups) through the South Asia Subregional Cooperation (SASEC) program.1 
BBIN have identified tourism development as a priority for subregional cooperation, and ongoing 
TA supports the meetings of the tourism working group (TWG). Nepal chairs the TWG, which 
has met three times since 2001, most recently in July 2003, in New Delhi, India. The TWG, at its 
second meeting, identified the preparation of a subregional tourism master plan as a priority 
program, and requested ADB for TA to support this.2 An advisory TA is, accordingly, included in 
the  regional  cooperation  strategy  and  program  for  2003.3  The  third  meeting  of  the  TWG 
discussed  the  proposed  plan,  and  agreed  that  this  should  be  a  subregional  tourism 
development plan that builds upon master plans in the four countries. It was also agreed that 
the planning should start with two common themes—(i) ecotourism based on the natural and 
cultural heritage of the subregion and (ii) Buddhist circuits in BBIN—and establish a thematic 
framework for tourism development. The plan will also outline an implementation program and 
help set the TWG’s future agenda. The TA framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  The World Tourism Organization (WTO) Tourism 2020 Vision forecasts that international 
arrivals will reach over 1.56 billion by 2020. Of these, 1.18 billion will be intraregional and 380 
million will be long-haul travelers. South Asia, which was one of the success stories of 2000, 
with tourist arrivals growing by 11%, is forecast to record an average annual growth of 6.2% 
over 1995–2020, compared to the world average of 4.1%. WTO preliminary estimates show that 
international tourist arrivals in 2002 exceeded 700 million, an increase of 3.1% over the year, 
demonstrating tourism’s resilience in the face of geopolitical uncertainty and an overall weak 
economy. However, growth was only 2% in South Asia. International tourism arrivals in South 
Asia made up only less than 1% of the world total.4  
 
3.  The  World  Travel  and  Tourism  Council  (WTTC)  estimates  the  economic  value  of 
personal travel and tourism in South Asia at $18.7 billion in 2003, growing by 7.3% per annum 
in real terms.5 By 2013 this is projected to reach $52.2 billion but would still be only a small 
fraction of world travel and tourism, projected at $3,862 billion by 2013. The overall economic 
impact of travel and tourism in South Asia is expected to contribute 4.8% to gross domestic 
product(GDP) in 2003, rising to 5.3% in 2013. The industry is projected to provide employment 
to about 29 million people (5.2% of the total) in 2003, and to almost 36 million (5.4%) in 2013. 
WTTC also monitors competitiveness indicators to assess to what extent a country offers a

high on price competitiveness, they rank low on other indicators such as (i) level of basic 
infrastructure  development,  (ii)  awareness  of  environmental  aspects  of  development,  (iii) 
advances in modern technological systems and infrastructure, (iv) human resources in tourism 
activity, (v) tourism openness (including visa requirements), and (vi) social development. 
 
4.  Geographically,  ecologically,  and  culturally  diverse,  SASEC  is  very  attractive  to 
international tourists. Its tourism resources range from the world’s highest mountain peaks in 
Nepal, to the vast cultural and physical diversity of India, the world’s longest sea beach and 
largest mangrove forest in Bangladesh, and the serene and beautiful mountain kingdom of 
Bhutan.  SASEC  already  receives  more  than  3  million  international  visitors  per  year,  each 
spending on average $1,073 per visit. In 2000 the combined total revenue from international 
tourists in the subregion was $3,531 million.6 The subregion also has tourist source markets of 
its own. Indian outbound tourists ranked first among tourist arrivals of all three neighbors, 
accounting for 28% of total tourist arrivals to these countries in 2000. The heads of tourism in 
BBIN agree that intraregional travel will be at least as significant as interregional travel to the 
future growth of tourism in the subregion. 
 
5.  As  well  as  bringing  in  foreign  exchange,  creating  jobs,  and  contributing  to  overall 
economic growth, SASEC tourism is particularly attractive as it promotes rural development. 
The subregion has styles of tourism such as overland cultural tours and mountain trekking that 
are suitable to spread benefits of tourism to the rural poor. The world’s leading examples of 
development programs using ecotourism to reduce rural poverty have come from the subregion. 
ADB’s experience of supporting ecotourism development in Nepal has shown that community-
based tourism can help reduce poverty and conserve the natural and cultural heritage.7 Project 
impacts include (i) increased employment, although seasonal; (ii) increased community capacity 
to manage small enterprises; (iii) increased food production due to additional tourist demand; 
and  (iv)  improved  maintenance  of  local  infrastructure  (e.g.,  campsites  and  trails)  through 
community  participation.  ADB’s  approach  has  combined  improving  airport  infrastructure  in 
remote rural areas with using locally developed training techniques to enable villagers to benefit 
from  the  resulting  increased  tourist  flows.  Opportunities  for  this  type  of  approach  occur 
throughout the subregion, building upon lessons learned from experience.8 
 
6.  ADB’s experience in the Greater Mekong Subregion (GMS) has illustrated tourism’s 
great potential as a sector for subregional cooperation. Cooperation among the six countries in 
GMS created the Mekong region, in which the whole has become greater than the sum of its 
parts. The TWG is aware of the potential for a similar South Asia region. The TWG’s Tourism 
Sector Working Group Report and Pre-investment Survey created this awareness and instilled 
in SASEC countries a strong willingness to cooperate.9 However, hurdles must be overcome. As 
with GMS at the outset, one significant hurdle is the lack of a subregional perspective in tourism 
planning. Until now, no one has had reason to look beyond national borders to identify patterns 
of tourism in the subregion and the potential to influence and enhance them. A subregional view 
of tourism plans in the four countries is required, drawing comparisons across borders and 
identifying opportunities for joint development and marketing of shared resources.

7.  The TWG report and survey established the general issues and constraints, and also 
identified development opportunities and project ideas based on the countries’ development 
priorities. The success of the TWG’s programs will depend on the following: (i) the will to work 
together; (ii) thematically packaged quality tourism products; (iii) a strong network of air, road, 
and rail access; (iv) easy visa and other facilitation formalities; and (v) a workforce able to 
implement the programs.  
 
8.  Besides subregional tourism planning, the TWG report and survey also recommended (i) 
establishing a SASEC tourism secretariat in one country; (ii) a joint marketing and promotional 
program; (iii) a common SASEC visa; (iv) key development projects to ensure good access by 
air, road, rail, and river; (v) a subregional human resource development study; (vi) a program of 
thematic tours; and (vii) use of the New Asian Highway (Singapore to Turkey) as the backbone 
for overland travel in BBIN. The TWG has narrowed its marketing focus to “ecotourism based on 
natural and cultural heritage of the subregion” and “Buddhist circuits in BBIN.” A subregional 
tourism development plan is required to refine and prioritize projects on these themes, and to 
create a framework program and plan of action for the TWG. Such cooperative planning will 
facilitate and enable tourism growth in South Asia. 
 
9.  Regional groupings such as the Agency for Coordinating Mekong Tourism Activities and 
South  Pacific  Tourism  Organization  combine  resources  for  cost-effective  joint  marketing 
initiatives  as  well  as  market  research  and  analyses.  As  illustrated  in  GMS,  subregional 
destination marketing can be effective and produce great efficiencies of scale. The subregional 
tourism development plan will identify projects for joint destination marketing aimed at intra- and 
interregional tourist markets. The need to upgrade the quality of tourism products will be met 
through projects involving public-private partnerships in infrastructure, promoting links between 
tourism and the conservation of the cultural and physical environment, and overcoming human 
resource  development  constraints  through  joint  training  of  trainers.  Opportunities  will  be 
identified to create an enabling environment for growth through public-private partnerships and 
developing mechanisms to facilitate private sector investment in tourism development. 
 
10.  The TWG has confirmed the basic strategic objectives for subregional cooperation in 
tourism: (i) develop a cooperative spirit among the tourism industries of the subregion, (ii) 
contribute to sustainable economic growth, (iii) use ecotourism to reduce poverty, (iv) create 
jobs, and (v) facilitate private sector investment in tourism.10 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Purpose and Output 
11.  The TA’s purpose is to prepare, with active participation of BBIN’s tourism sectors, a 
SASEC tourism development plan (TDP) that will provide a thematic framework of programs 
and projects for future subregional cooperation activities of the TWG. The TA will help achieve, 
through subregional cooperation, significant growth in tourism, leading to overall economic 
growth and reduction of rural poverty in SASEC. 
 
12.  The main output will be a SASEC TDP for 2004–2014, which will include (i) a framework 
program under which TWG activities will be structured around the two themes, (ii) specific 
project ideas and concept plans for appropriate tourism development in key areas where

tourism  resources  are  shared  by  two  or  more  countries,  and  (iii)  project  ideas  for  joint 
destination marketing.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
13.  The TA’s participatory approach will involve the tourism industry’s public and private 
sectors and other stakeholders in developing a framework program and project concepts. After 
some initial research, national workshops with the tourism industry and stakeholders will be held 
in each SASEC country, hosted by the national tourism organizations (NTOs). Draft project 
ideas for marketing, infrastructure, human resource development, facilitation of travel, key area 
development,  and  development  mechanisms  will  be  debated  and  agreed  on  at  these 
workshops. Later, the TWG will participate in a subregional workshop at which draft results of 
the study, including an outline action plan, will be presented and discussed. The subregional 
workshop will also debate and agree on the future program, roles, and procedures of the 
working group. 
 
14.  The TA will (i) review and build on SASEC tourism planning to date; (ii) analyze existing 
subregional  tourism  markets,  marketing,  product  demand  and  supply,  cost  and  quality 
competitiveness, and constraints on tourism growth; (iii) review national, state, and district 
plans, priorities, and institutional frameworks for tourism development, with particular reference 
to the two themes;11 (iv) consider other national policies, laws, and regulations across sectors 
that may affect, or be affected by, the economic, social, and ecological impacts of tourism 
development;  (v)  identify  and  coordinate  with  prospective  partner  agencies,  including 
development partners; (vi) identify key tourism resources shared by countries, and prepare 
concept plans for tourism development associated with these; (vii) prepare a draft framework 
program and project ideas for discussion with stakeholders, to evolve a widely accepted final 
output;  (viii)  outline  cost-effective  ways  to  promote  the  themes  to  intra- and interregional 
markets through joint destination marketing; (ix) identify, according to agreed-on screening and 
selection criteria, project ideas to develop physical infrastructure to facilitate tourism growth, 
giving highest priority to projects shared by countries; (x) identify human resource development 
needs and propose a program to train trainers in tourism, covering government agencies, the 
private sector, entrepreneurs, and communities; (xi) identify needed improvements in tourism 
facilities at border crossings and other improvements to facilitate travel; (xii) outline subregional 
guidelines for tourism development, including criteria for a subregional code of conduct and 
good  practice  for  the  tourism  industry;  ways  to  ensure  sustainable  development  and 
management of tourism in protected areas; and ways to protect and enhance the rights of 
indigenous  people,  particularly  those  living  in  border  areas;  (xiii)  develop  mechanisms, 
especially financial ones, to facilitate private sector investment in tourism development, and 
ways to link the private sector with communities; (xiv) prepare an action plan to implement the 
framework program, basic guidelines for each country’s participation, and a timeframe for 
implementation; (xv) recommend roles and procedures for the TWG and other key players in 
implementation. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The TA is estimated to cost $450,000, and will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s TA 
funding program. Details of the cost estimates are given in Appendix 2.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  ADB will be the Executing Agency for the TA. The work will be undertaken on behalf of 
the TWG and carried out in close cooperation with BBIN tourism ministries and NTOs to 
promote ownership and facilitate implementation and field work. ADB will coordinate with other 
working groups and the South Asia Business Forum established under the SASEC program. 
The focal points nominated by the NTOs will work closely with the consultants’ team to prepare 
the TDP. 
 
17.  The TA will be implemented over 6 months, from December 2003 to May 2004. A total of 
18 person-months of consulting services will be required: 8 person-months of international 
consulting,  comprising  expertise  in  tourism  planning,  tourism  marketing  and  product 
development, and tourism financing; and 10 person-months of national tourism specialists, with 
expertise in tourism planning and tourism economics. ADB will recruit an international consulting 
firm in association with domestic consultants, in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use 
of Consultants and other arrangements satisfactory to ADB on the engagement of domestic 
consultants. The selection of consultants will be done using the biodata proposal procedure, 
and advance action will be taken to recruit the consultants. Outline terms of reference are in 
Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The TA consultants will prepare the following: (i) an inception report 2.0 weeks after the 
TA starts, detailing the work program and criteria to screen and select project ideas; (ii) an 
interim report presenting the findings and outlining a framework program and project ideas, 
about 3.0 months after the TA starts and when the series of national workshops with the tourism 
industry and other stakeholders is completed; (iii) a draft final report at the end of 4.5 months; 
(iv) a subregional workshop at the end of 5.0 months, to coincide with a meeting of the TWG 
tentatively planned to be held in Bhutan; and (v) a final report by the  end of 6.0 months, 
incorporating feedback from the subregional workshop and comments on the draft final report, 
and including an action plan defining implementation steps and responsibilities.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $450,000 on a grant basis for 
the South Asia Subregional Economic Cooperation Tourism Development Plan, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require the services of about 8 person-months of 
international consultants in tourism planning, tourism marketing and product development, and 
tourism financing; and a total of 10 person-months of national consultants—four specialists in 
tourism planning (one from each participating country) and one specialist in tourism economics 
from the subregion. All specialists will do the following:  
 
(i)  Ensure that the tourism development plan (TDP) builds on the Tourism Sector 
Working Group Report and Pre-Investment Survey and all other reports and 
papers  associated  with  the  South  Asia  Subregional  Economic  Cooperation 
(SASEC) tourism sector. 
(ii)  Participate in the inception planning workshop. 
(iii)  Coordinate with activities of other related working groups and the South Asia 
Business Forum established under SASEC. 
(iv)  Attend national industry workshops in each country to discuss and agree on 
project ideas. 
(v)  Participate in the final SASEC tourism working group (TWG) workshop at which 
draft results of the study will be presented, and the roles and procedures of TWG 
discussed and agreed on. 
(vi)  Contribute to reports and other outputs as required, following Asian Development 
Bank (ADB) guidelines. 
(vii)  Provide any other assistance the team leader may require. 
 
A.  Tourism Planning Specialist and Team Leader (international, 3.5 person-months) 
2.  The tourism planning specialist, who will also be the team leader, will coordinate the 
inputs and work plans of all team members. The specialist will make all analyses necessary to 
prepare  the  SASEC  TDP  to  develop  socially,  culturally,  and  environmentally  sustainable 
subregional tourism, consulting widely with the tourism industry in Bangladesh, Bhutan, India 
and Nepal (BBIN). This task will involve desk and field studies. Specifically the team leader will 
work with team members to do the following: 
  
(i)  Review existing and likely future tourism patterns in the subregion and use them 
to elicit inputs from industry regarding constraints on tourism growth. 
(ii)  Hold a planning workshop at inception for the consulting team. 
(iii)  Establish the planning context by presenting an overview of existing national, 
state,  and  district  plans,  priorities,  and  institutional  frameworks  for  tourism 
development. Early in the process, gather and review all existing national, state, 
and district plans and priorities for tourism development. Also gather and review 
national sectoral policies, laws, and regulations that may affect or be affected by 
tourism development, and any published information on the potential impacts of 
tourism. Summarize each national picture, paying attention to the prospects for 
tourism growth. 
(iv)  Approach prospective partners (bilateral and multilateral aid agencies, public and 
private sector agencies, nongovernment organizations) that may be willing to 
help implement the TWG’s programs, analyze the motivations of the agencies, 
and seek opportunities to involve the them in the remainder of the planning 
study, specifying the nature of the envisaged assistance. 
(v)  Propose a draft framework of program headings and specific project ideas under 
which future TWG activities will be structured, fully incorporating the TWG’s

10  Appendix 3 
decision at its third meeting to focus its activities on (a) ecotourism based on 
natural and cultural heritage of the subregion and (b) Buddhist circuits in BBIN. 
(vi)  Discuss  the  draft  with  stakeholders  during  the  study  and  evolve  a  widely 
accepted framework. 
(vii)  Include project ideas for joint destination marketing, outlining how the public and 
private sectors can collaborate in practical, cost-effective ways to promote the 
themes to intra- and interregional markets. 
(viii)  Include project ideas to develop physical infrastructure associated with facilitating 
tourism  growth,  giving  highest  priority  to  projects  shared  by  two  or  more 
countries. 
(ix)  Include project ideas to train trainers, focusing on the tourism-related human 
resource  development  needs  of  government  agencies,  private  sector, 
entrepreneurs, and communities. 
(x)  Include project ideas to improve tourism facilities at border crossings and those 
to facilitate travel associated with the themes. 
(xi)  Include outline subregional guidelines for tourism development, including criteria 
for a subregional code of conduct for the tourism industry and actions required in 
other fields such as environmental and social impact assessment. 
(xii)  Identify key areas where tourism resources are shared by countries, and prepare 
concept plans to develop tourism in these areas. 
(xiii)  Include  project  ideas  to  develop  mechanisms,  especially  financial  ones,  to 
facilitate private sector investment in tourism development associated with the 
themes. 
(xiv)  Present an action plan outlining the steps to implement the framework programs, 
basic  guidelines  for  each  country’s  participation,  and  a  timeframe  for 
implementation.  
(xv)  Hold national industry workshops in each SASEC country, to be hosted by the 
national tourism organizations (NTOs), at which draft project ideas for marketing, 
infrastructure,  human  resource  development,  facilitation  of  travel,  key  area 
development, and development mechanisms will be debated and agreed on.  
(xvi)  Conduct a TWG workshop at which draft results of the study will be presented 
and discussed, and the roles and procedures of the TWG debated and agreed 
on. 
(xvii)  Recommend  roles  and  procedures  of  the  TWG  and  other  key  players  in 
implementation. 
(xviii)  With the tourism marketing and product development specialist, prepare the final 
TDP. 
 
B.  Tourism Marketing and Product Development Specialist (international, 2.5 person-
months) 
3.  The specialist will provide inputs on subregional marketing and product development for 
the TDP. The specialist will make all necessary analyses to develop socially, culturally, and 
environmentally sustainable subregional tourism by undertaking desk and field studies, and 
attending  and/or  conducting  workshops  as  required.  Specifically  the  specialist  will  do  the 
following: 
 
(i)  Help  (a) review existing and likely future tourism patterns in the subregion, 
including subregional tourism markets, marketing, product demand and supply, 
cost and quality competitiveness, and constraints on tourism growth; and (b) 
establish the overall planning context and partner agencies.

(ii)  Help draft the framework program and project ideas focusing activities on the 
themes  and  taking  into  account  tourism  product  development,  physical 
infrastructure, general services, tourism investment, training needs, and potential 
impacts of tourism. 
(iii)  Help outline subregional guidelines for tourism development, including criteria for 
a subregional code of conduct for the tourism industry. 
(iv)  Develop project ideas for joint destination marketing, outlining how the public and 
private sector can collaborate in  practical, cost-effective ways to promote the 
themes to intra- and interregional markets.  
(v)  With  the  team,  develop  project  ideas  to  identify  key  areas  where  tourism 
resources are shared by two or more countries and help prepare concept plans 
to develop tourism in these areas. 
(vi)  With  the  team  leader,  develop  an  action  plan  to  implement  the  framework 
program. 
(vii)  With the team leader, conduct national industry workshops in each SASEC

resource  development,  facilitation  of  travel,  key  area  development,  and 
development of mechanisms. 
(viii)  With the team leader, prepare the final SASEC TDP. 
 
C.  Tourism Finance Specialist (international, 2 person-months) 
4.  The specialist will provide inputs on subregional investment for the SASEC TDP study 
following ADB guidelines. The specialist will analyze financing the development of socially, 
culturally, and environmentally sustainable tourism, and explore the viability of establishing a 
funding facility to stimulate tourism in the subregion. This task will involve desk and field studies, 
interacting with financial institutions and the private sector, and attending and/or conducting 
focus group discussions and workshops as required. Specifically the specialist will do the 
following: 
 
(i)  Help  review tourism patterns in the subregion, overall planning context, and 
prospective partner agencies from an investment perspective. 
(ii)  Review government tourism policy in general, and fiscal incentives to the tourism 
sector in particular, in each country. 
(iii)  Help draft the framework program and specific project ideas focusing on the 
themes, taking into account investment and funding imperatives. 
(iv)  Assess the overall amount of financial resources required to implement the 
SASEC TDP. 
(v)  Guide the work of the national tourism economist. 
(vi)  Develop recommendations for a funding facility program, outlining ways the 
public and private sector can collaborate to promote investment for tourism 
infrastructure and product development. 
(vii)  With the team, develop funding ideas for key areas where tourism resources are 
shared by countries, and help prepare concept development plans for tourism in 
these areas. 
(viii)  Help outline subregional guidelines for tourism development, including criteria for 
a subregional code of conduct for the tourism industry. 
(ix)  With the team leader, develop an action plan to implement the funding facility of 
the framework program. 
(x)  With the team leader, conduct national industry workshops in each country to 
debate and agree on project ideas.

12  Appendix 3 
 
D.  Tourism Planning Specialists (national, 8 person-months) 
5.  The specialists (one from each country) will provide inputs on tourism for the SASEC 
TDP  and  determine  how  to  develop  socially,  culturally,  and  environmentally  sustainable 
subregional tourism. The specialists will work closely with NTO staff nominated as the focal 
point. The work will involve conducting desk and field studies, and attending workshops as 
required. Each specialist will, with the guidance of the team leader, do the following: 
 
(i)  Review and analyze existing and likely future tourism patterns in the country and 
subregion, including tourism markets, marketing, product demand and supply, 
cost and quality competitiveness and the constraints on tourism growth. 
(ii)  Prepare an overview of the relevant national, state, and district plans, priorities, 
and institutional frameworks that relate to tourism. 
(iii)  Prepare an overview of other national sectoral policies, laws, and regulations that 
may affect or be affected by the economic, social, and ecological impacts of 
tourism development.  
(iv)  Help identify prospective partner agencies in the country and subregion. 
(v)  Identify  national  tourism-related  human  resource  development  needs  of 
government agencies, private sector, individual entrepreneurs, and communities; 
and outline the needs of training trainers. 
(vi)  Help  draft  framework  program  headings  and  project  ideas,  focusing  on  the 
themes,  taking  into  account  tourism  product  development,  marketing  and 
promotion,  physical  infrastructure,  general  services,  tourism  investment,  and 
training needs. 
(vii)  With  the  team,  develop  project  ideas  and  identify  key  areas  where  tourism 
resources can be shared by countries, and help prepare concept plans for 
tourism development in these areas. 
(viii)  With the team, outline subregional guidelines for tourism development, including 
criteria for a subregional code of conduct and good practice for the tourism 
industry, ways to ensure sustainable development and management of tourism in 
protected areas, and ways to preserve and protect and enhance the rights of 
indigenous people, particularly those living in border areas. 
(ix)  Organize and attend national industry workshops to debate and agree on draft 
project  ideas  for  marketing,  infrastructure,  human  resource  development, 
facilitation of travel, key area development, and mechanism development.  
(x)  Work closely with NTO staff appointed as the focal point, and coordinate with the 
team leader and tourism marketing and product development specialist. 
 
E.  Tourism Economist (national, 2 person-months) 
6.  The  consultant  will  be  from  one  of  the  participating  countries,  and  will  have  a 
background and experience in assessing financial and economic costs and benefits of tourism-
related projects. The consultant will work closely with the national tourism planning specialists 
and under the guidance of the international tourism finance specialist, and will be responsible 
for the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Assess  the  economic  impacts  of  subregional  cooperation  in  tourism,  with 
reference to economic growth and employment. 
(ii)  Broadly quantify the net benefits of identified projects in economic and financial 
terms, including consideration for ecological aspects.

Appendix 3  13 
(iii)  Prepare preliminary financing and investment needs, and examine all possible 
financing options (local, national, and external).  
 
F.  Workshop Facilitators and Experts 
7.  The team leader will, with concurrence of ADB, select experts to contribute to and 
facilitate discussions at the national workshops and the final seminar, on topics of relevance to 
subregional development planning. Specialist inputs will be related to tourism trends, market 
analysis and marketing, economics of tourism, pro-poor tourism development, tourism law, and 
environmental  and  social  impacts  of  tourism  on  other  country-specific  aspects  promoting 
socially, culturally, and environmentally sustainable tourism. The team leader will identify the 
experts during his or her first round of country visits, after discussions with the national tourism 
planning specialists and the country’s NTO focal point. The experts will be required to undertake 
desk research and present a paper to a national industry workshop.
